quotes: he accused Johnson, as well as Michael Gove, of behaving 'appallingly' during the referendum campaign of 2016.
In September 2020, Cameron became the fifth former prime minister to criticise the UK Internal Market Bill
Cameron published a memoir, For the Record, on 19 September 2019 through HarperCollins.
According to the Guardian, the book was initially scheduled for 2018, but was delayed so Cameron would not be perceived as a 'backstreet driver' in the ongoing Brexit negotiations.
In 2018 he became an advisor to Greensill Capital and held share options in the company
In 2019 Cameron arranged for a private meeting with Lex Greensill and Secretary of State for Health and Social Care Matt Hancock;
In 2020 a few months before Greensill Capital collapsed, Cameron lobbied the government to bend the rules to allow it to receive Covid Corporate Financing Facility loans.
